reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction to Hong Kong taxation and tax administration
2. Property tax: Scope of charge
3. Salaries tax: Scope of charge; Income & expenses; Personal allowances; Computation & Planning
4. Profits tax: Scope of charge; Source of Profits; Deemed trading receipts; Deductions

No time to teach profits tax computation this semester, thank god!!

Other topics that are not covered as scheduled:
- Tax depreciation allowances
- Personal assessment
- Anti-tax avoidance; tax evasion & penalty
- Stamp duty: Scope of charge; different Heads of charge; Relief and exemption; stamp duty administration; stamp duty planning
- Ethical issues & Introduction to tax related to cross-border transactions
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kelvin’s teaching is quite good. He knows very well about the course content and always taught us how to write like 'tax people'.
His powerpoint is very simple and he always illustrates with examples during class to make things easier to be understood. But his words are so small and everything is packed. He usually writes everything on paper before class and just shows you the paper during class. Then he starts explaining about the example, which makes me don't wanna copy the illustration or listen to it at all.
I think Kelvin tried his best to explain the basic concept but you need to read books and do exercises to understand all the stuff.

The mean of each assignment fluctuates but I think is around 25% overall

Mid-term examination 25%: 10MC 3LQ
Me 75.5/100 Mean: 67.35 High: 93.5

Final examination 40%: 20MC 5LQ
Not released, have a question from ACCA past paper with slight changes.

Final grade: A+
自問好多野都唔係好識。。。 midterm又唔係高分。。。 覺得個course好靚grade 多謝kelvin!!

reviews.comment_content:
Topics to be covered:
- Introduction to Hong Kong taxation and tax administration
- Property tax: Scope of charge

- Personal allowances; Computation & Planning

I remember the midterm examination has a subpart that is very similar to the example not uploaded to Canvas, you just need to change the figures to answer that question.

reviews.comment_workload:
It depends on which grade you wanna obtain :p

Attending lecture/watching lecture video is highly recommended (Kelvin will explain difficult concepts)

*****You must read TEXTBOOK!!!!! Kelvin wrote this textbook for UG students and concepts are illustrated in plain English. You would have better understanding about each topic through browsing the explanation and examples in textbook.
(I am lazy during the semester but I force myself to read the textbook before midterm and final exam)

Take Home Ex is challenging and Kelvin will modify assignment each semester (we cannot copy ^^)

Doing ACCA past paper and Textbook examples are also highly recommended. Kelvin's lectures just present you the theory but not the application. Drilling past paper would consolidate your concepts and Kelvin's paper are similar to ACCA paper :)

Heavy workload for sure since each assignment is difficult and I am extremely stressful about exams. But you should believe your effort will pay off!!

reviews.comment_teaching: Kelvin is quite funny and he give plenty of examples for each concepts. Yet, he is ONLY willing to answer questions after class, not through emails. Everytime I sent emails ask him questions, I got no reply! So it is kind of self study and self learn from answer keys and mistakes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Discussion and participation (5%)
In-class ex. (20%) (62/66, mean: 59.4)
Midterm (25%) (49/70, mean: 47, sd: 5)
Final (50%) (not release)

For in-class ex, it is group assignment. There are 5 exercises in total. He said he would only count the best few in the first class so I am not sure if he counts all. Some answers can be found online so the mean is quite close to full mark.

Examinations are both open book open notes. Doing ACCA questions are quite useful as 1 midterm question is copied from ACCA. Besides, only reading notes is not enough and ACCA questions provide more practice opportunities and examples.

For midterm, there are 3 questions on topic 1 to 3 (exclude salaries tax computation). There are 1 question on tax administration and offense, 1 on property tax computation, and 1 on salaries tax scope and source.

For final, there are 4 questions on all topics. There are 1 on profits tax computation, 1 on salaries tax computation (2 year comp with explanations) and personal assessment, 1 on depreciation allowance, 1 on profits tax scope and source. Kelvin will tell you about each question on the last class so do attend it! The final counts for half of the grade, not to mention that it will be on the last exam day, so you should definitely spend more time to study.

->Finally A grade!
I did all the related ACCA and textbook questions so I think my efforts pay off!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite low as there is no projects. But you have to spend extra time sort out relevant ACCA questions, do the textbook and ACCA questions.

reviews.author: Kody
reviews.title: Just relying notes is not enough
reviews.comment_content:
Very basic content for learning about HK tax. Spent about a month talking about HK tax administration issues, then 2 weeks on Property Tax and 3 weeks on Salaries Tax. The remainder of the course focused on Profits Tax (including Depreciation Allowance) and spent 1 class on Personal Assessment.
Kelvin prepared slides on Stamp Duty as well, but we didn't have enough time to cover that.

In-class participation+3 In-class exercises+Mid-term+Final

Exams are all open-book.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Tax is a very complicated subject, and Kelvin has good exposure in the industry before. Kelvin tried very hard to explain the concepts and tax rule. You think you knew what he said but when you started to do the practice questions, you have no idea what's going on. That's why it's very important to read the textbook (ideally before attending class). Kelvin will try to raise different examples in class to discuss, which is nice if the class is responsive. By the way, Kelvin speaks in a very nice accent.

After grading the midterm paper, don't argue with TA Sandy. It doesn't work.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't know if Kelvin gives a bad grade or not since I don't know about the final exam score. But Kelvin did talk about the topics that are going to be reflected in the exams beforehand, so you can prepare accordingly.

TA is strict on grading the paper. She once said to me, "If the exam is closed-book, you can get the mark, but the exam is open-book, so I cannot give you the mark".
reviews.comment_workload:
This course is intensive. Unlike other ACCT courses, this course requires you to read the textbook thoroughly. Just relying on Kelvin's PPT will lead you nowhere. The textbook is very well written and extremely easy to follow, so it helps a lot.

And also, do ACCA past exam papers when preparing for the exams. I noticed a question in the final appeared to be a deviation from one of the questions in ACCA. So the ideal situation is to print out the ACCA papers and answers before attending the exam and bring them in.

reviews.author: acct :P
reviews.comment_content: The course provides students with an understanding of the relevant tax statutes; case law principles and tax practices concerning Hong Kong taxation. The course focuses on direct taxes as well as stamp duty in Hong Kong. Other essential topics that include tax administration procedures under the Inland Revenue Ordinance; contemporary tax practice and tax planning principles; anti-tax avoidance and tax issues relating to cross-border transactions would also be covered. ACCT5410 is such a comprehensive taxation course that aims at giving students a solid foundation that enables them to address and deal with tax issues pertaining to business transactions effectively.
reviews.comment_teaching: The pace is quite slow sometimes. special accent.Many illustrations are uploaded to Canvas.
reviews.comment_grading: The quiz may be hard for someone who is unfamilar with the textbooks. To get a good grade in the final exam, you need do the acca taxation exercise.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light.No mid-term exam but a quiz, consisting of 15 multiple choice questions. Fewer assignments compared with other courses.
